Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Meta-Ecosystems and the Upstream Legacy: Influence of Dissolved Organic Matter on the Structure and Function of Streambed Bacterial Communities
Award.AbstractNarration:
Organic carbon, in the form of dissolved molecules transported in stream water, is processed for energy by microorganisms that live on the streambed. That processing constitutes a critical link in the global carbon cycle. The sources of much of the stream carbon are the upper layer of soils within small watersheds and algae that live in streams. Looking out over a drainage network, the investigators will explore how the quality of the organic molecules changes with distance downstream and how those changes influence the composition of the communities of streambed microbes using that food resource. To characterize the thousands of individual organic molecules dissolved in stream water and the vast diversity of microorganisms living in streams, the research team will exploit novel methods that link the new frontiers in molecular microbiology and analytical organic geochemistry. This proposal will be carried out in waters that range in size from small streams to small rivers within temperate and tropical forests. The research goals include advancing knowledge of stream ecosystems across drainage networks and forging a broad model of stream ecosystems in the global carbon cycle.

Understanding the global carbon cycle is a critical scientific need of society and recent studies suggest that freshwater streams and rivers play a significant role within it. By better understanding the relationships between stream microorganisms and the organic carbon in freshwater streams, this study will contribute to our overall understanding of a key component of the global carbon cycle. Because microorganisms are invisible to the naked eye, getting students excited about the diversity of microorganisms and organic molecules and the complexity of their ecological interactions is difficult. The research team will develop educational materials that depict the basic concepts in microbiology and organic geochemistry with an emphasis on the vital roles that microorganisms play in aquatic ecosystems. At facilities within each of the study catchments the investigators and their educator colleagues will hold two-day summer teacher workshops to expose secondary school teacher to the microbial world of streams. The workshops will be timed to allow participants to mirror the field and laboratory activities of the scientists. In addition, 1 graduate student, 1 post-doctoral scientist, and 7 undergraduates will receive training during the project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The River Continuum Concept (RCC), developed in early 1980s, provides an important framework and conceptual model for river ecosystem research. Lacking the benefit of knowledge from the new frontiers in molecular microbiology and ultra-high resolution geochemistry, composition of dissolved organic matter (DOM) and microbial community structures were not included in the original RCC. In headwater streams, DOM provides an energy source and building blocks for the microorganisms that dominate aquatic ecosystem respiration and biogeochemical cycling. Therefore how DOM structure interacts with the microbial community is a central question within freshwater ecosystem science.  This award specifically addressed the above question by investigating the detailed molecular-level composition of DOM and the dynamics of DOM and the bacterial populations that depend upon DOM as their food resource, along riverine networks.

Three well-characterized forested catchments with streams ranging from the smallest streams that constitute the beginnings of river systems through mid-sized rivers downstream were included in this study: Neversink in New York, White Clay Creek in Pennsylvania, and Rio Tempisquito in Costa Rica (Fig. 1). Twelve successful sampling campaigns were conducted and a total of 163 samples (84 sediments and 79 rock surface scrapings) were collected from different locations and seasons across watersheds. Detailed DOM molecular composition and microbial community structure were characterized with FT-ICR Mass Spectrometry and next generation sequencing, respectively. In addition, metadata including water chemistry and physical measurements were also included in the analyses.

Significant findings from the project include: (1) A new high throughput sequencing platform, the PacBio SMRT chip, used for analyses of a variety of environmental samples offers accurate full sequences of 16S ribosomal RNA genes with the possibility of identifying microorganisms to the species level in environmental samples. This development of the new PacBio RS II system with upgraded hardware and enzyme chemistry has the potential to influence ecosystem science and microbial ecology. (2) Stream waters in different climatic regions contained distinctive dissolved organic matter (DOM) compositions. Lignin-like and tannin-like molecules were the abundant components in DOM composition: 48% of all formulas were found in all streams while ~20% of the DOM molecules were unique to watersheds. Within a fluvial network, DOM elemental composition revealed distinct downstream gradients such as a decline in compound richness, numbers of tannin-like and lignin-like molecules, and condensed hydrocarbon-like molecules. Headwaters (the smallest streams where ground waters come to the surface and coalesce into a stream channel) contained the most unique DOM formula, and downstream sites were characterized by more cosmopolitan molecules. (3) The most upstream waters are repository of microbial diversity, and bacterial richness and diversity are reduced in a downstream direction as streams get larger. Comprehensive bacterial community analyses and multivariate statistics indicated that bacterial distributions in headwaters are primarily driven by watersheds, substrates, stream orders and seasons. These results provide novel molecular information on the composition of bacterial communities and the biogeographic distribution of their constituent populations in freshwater environments. (4) Another current and future contribution from this project is the resolution of the longitudinal linkage of bacterial communities and dissolved organic matter composition throughout a stream network.
